original_data.question: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son with a fever over the past day. The patient’s son adds that his father has been having some behavioral problems, as well, and that he was complaining about bugs crawling over his skin this morning even though there were no insects. Past medical history is unremarkable. No current medications. The patient was an alcoholic for several years but abruptly quit drinking 5 days ago. The patient’s temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F), pulse is 130/min, blood pressure is 146/88 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, he is confused, restless, agitated, and lacks orientation to time, place or person. Which of the following the most appropriate initial course of treatment of this patient?

model_response:
The patient’s presentation is consistent with delirium. Delirium is characterized by acute onset, clouding of consciousness, disorientation, and a variety of other cognitive and perceptual abnormalities. The most common cause of delirium in the elderly is medication: drugs with anticholinergic activity, narcotics, sedativehypnotics, and alcohol. Other causes of delirium include infection, trauma, hypoxia, hypovolemia, substance abuse, metabolic derangements, and central nervous system tumors or vascular lesions. The initial treatment of delirium involves correction of the underlying cause, including the discontinuation of offending medications. The patient’s agitation and restlessness can be treated with a neuroleptic agent such as haloperidol (5-10 mg orally or intravenously). Chlorpromazine and thioridazine are also effective in treating agitation and restlessness, but they have a higher incidence of side effects than haloperidol. Clonidine, a central alpha-adrenergic agonist, may also be used to treat agitation in delirium, but it is less effective than haloperidol. Diazepam is a sedative-hypnotic that may be used to treat agitation and insomnia in delirium, but it carries a risk of exacerbating the confusion and cognitive dysfunction.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
Occurring or done each day.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Male parents, human or animal.
Troublesome or disruptive behavioral displays.

Family of MITES in the superfamily Trombiculoidea, suborder Prostigmata, which attack humans and other vertebrates, causing DERMATITIS and severe allergic reactions. Chiggers, red bugs, and harvest mites commonly refer to the larval stage of Trombiculid mites, the only parasitic stage of the mite's life cycle.
Subjective cutaneous sensations of insects in the absence of stimulation.
The time period between dawn and noon.

Members of the phylum ARTHROPODA composed or organisms characterized by division into three parts: head, thorax, and abdomen. They are the dominant group of animals on earth with several hundred thousand different kinds. Three orders, HEMIPTERA; DIPTERA; and SIPHONAPTERA; are of medical interest in that they cause disease in humans and animals. (From Borror et al., An Introduction to the Study of Insects, 4th ed, p1).
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Occurring in or belonging to the present time.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Persons who have a history of physical or psychological dependence on ETHANOL.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

A state of restlessness associated with unpleasant feelings of irritability and tension. Causes include pain, stress, fever, alcohol and nicotine withdrawal, cocaine and hallucinogenic drugs use, depression, bipolar disorders, and schizophrenia.

A state of restlessness associated with unpleasant feelings of irritability and tension. Causes include pain, stress, fever, alcohol and nicotine withdrawal, cocaine and hallucinogenic drugs use, depression, bipolar disorders, and schizophrenia.
Awareness of oneself in relation to time, place and person.
The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. (McGraw-Hill Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms, 6th ed)

Persons as individuals (e.g., ABORTION APPLICANTS) or as members of a group (e.g., HISPANIC AMERICANS). It is not used for members of the various professions (e.g., PHYSICIANS) or occupations (e.g., LIBRARIANS) for which OCCUPATIONAL GROUPS is available.

Used with diseases for therapeutic interventions except drug therapy, diet therapy, radiotherapy, and surgery, for which specific subheadings exist. The concept is also used for articles and books dealing with multiple therapies.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
